review.title: Azhary: An Arabic Lexical Ontology
review.abstract: Arabic language is the most spoken languages in the Semitic languages group, and one of the most common languages in the world spoken by more than 422 million. It is also of paramount importance to Muslims, it is a sacred language of the Islamic Holly Book (Quran) and prayer (and other acts of worship) in Islam is performed only by mastering some of Arabic words. Arabic is also a major ritual language of a number of Christian churches in the Arab world and it is also used in writing several intellectual and religious Jewish books in the Middle Ages. Despite this, there is no semantic Arabic lexicon which researchers can depend on. In this paper we introduce Azhary as a lexical ontology for the Arabic language. It groups Arabic words into sets of synonyms called synsets, and records a number of relationships between words such as synonym, antonym, hypernym, hyponym, meronym, holonym and association relations. The ontology contains 26,195 words organized in 13,328 synsets. It has been developed and contrasted against AWN which is the most common available Arabic lexical ontology.

sections.heading: 1.1 The Arabic Language
sections.text: Language is a fundamental value in the life of any nation in which it carries ideas and concepts and establishes communication links between people.The language templates, the ideas, images and words that are formulated, in which feelings and emotions are never inseparable intellectual and emotional contents [1].The Arabic language is considered to be one of the most productive languages in terms of language material, for example, the Lisan El-Arabic (The Arabic Tongue) dictionary, developed in the 13th century, contains more than 80,000 elements, while in English the Samuel Johnson dictionary, considered to be one of the first English dictionaries developed in the 18th century, contains 42,000 words.The Arabic language contains 28 characters, or 29 characters if the Hamza is considered as a separate sign. The Arabic language is written from right to left like Persian, Hebrew, unlike many international languages and from top to bottom. It should be noted that the Arabic language includes Mandarin and dialects.

sections.heading: 1.2 The Semantic Web
sections.text: To solve these problems, Tim BernersLee introduced the Semantic Web as a conceptual model of the Web, in which content can be read and used by humans and intelligently by machines [2]. He mentioned that "the Semantic Web (SW) is not a separate Web, but an extension of the current one, in which information acquires a clearly defined meaning. Adding semantics to the Web involves allowing documents that have information in machine-readable forms, and creating links with relationship values." [3] Tim Berners-Lee introduced the fourth version of the Semantic Web Architecture with eight layers in 2006 [4]. The RDF and ontology are considered the most important layers of this structure. The Resource Description Framework (RDF) is considered the key infrastructure for the construction of the Semantic Web because it enables sectarian interoperability.It is a standardized foundation for the exchange of web resources that will be used on a large scale in 2001 DF code when it is structured.

sections.heading: 1.3 The Lexical Ontologies
sections.text: WordNet is a lexical database for the English language. It collects English words into groups of synonyms called synsets, gives short definitions and usage examples, and records a number of relationships between these synonyms. These relationships include: hypernym, hyponym, coordinate terms, meronym, holonym [7]. WordNet can be interpreted and used as lexical ontology. It has been used for a number of different purposes in information systems, including word sense disambiguation, information recovery, automatic text classification, automatic text aggregation, machine translation, and even automatic crossword generation [8]. The success of WordNet in the English language stimulated similar projects aimed at developing WordNets for other languages, making many WordNets an important resource for a wide range of natural language processing applications.

sections.heading: 2. Related works
sections.text: In recent years, much research has been published on the construction of Arab ontologies, which belong to different domains and are constructed using different methods.

sections.heading: 2.1. Islamic Domain Ontology
sections.text: Al-Yahya and others [12] proposed a computational model for the presentation of Arabic lexicographies using ontologies. Ontology development was based on the ontological development approach UPON (Unified Process for ONtology) [13]. Ontology was limited to time nominations that occurred in the Holy Quran. Ontology consisted of 18 classes and comprised a total of 59 words. Hikmat Ullah Khan and others [14] suggested that the ontology concept could be applied to the development of semantic search in the Holy Quran. They presented a domain ontology based on living beings, including animals and birds mentioned in the Holy Quran. Authors in [15] examined the representation and classification of the Holy Quran knowledge using ontology. The ontology model for the Al-Quran was developed according to Al-Quran knowledge topics as described in Syammil Al-Quran Miracle Reference.

sections.heading: 2.2. Linguistic Ontology
sections.text: The authors in [16] described the Semantic Quran Dataset as a multilingual RDF representation of the translations of the Quran. The dataset was created using two different semi-structured sources (The Tanzil Project, The Quranic Arabic Corpus Project), which focused on an ontology that represents multilingual data from sources with a hierarchical structure, and the resulting RDF data included 43 different languages that are among the most under-represented languages in linked data, including Arabic, Amharic and Amazigh. The authors presented the ontology developed for structuring the data, covering four basic classes: Chapter, Verses, Word and LexicalItem. Belkredim and El Sebai [17] developed Arabic ontology using verbs and roots, and classified verbs deriving the Arabic language from the roots.

sections.heading: 2.3. Automatic Ontology Generation
sections.text: [25] presented an approach to the automatic generation of ontology instances from a collection of unstructured well-known documents such as Al-Quran. The presented approach was based on the combination of techniques for processing natural language, information extraction and text mining. [26] presented an approach to the automatic ontology construction from a corpus of the domain of "Arabic linguistics," using information extraction techniques to extract new terms that denote elements of ontology (concept, relationship). [27] illustrated an ontology extraction based on a fuzzy-swarm algorithm for Islamic knowledge text. [28] proposed a system that improves the process of constructing a taxonomic ontology of the agricultural domain using a semi-automated web-specific document.

sections.heading: 2.4. Miscellanies Ontologies
sections.text: [29] presented multilingual tools for online search of Arabic information based on the ontology of the legal domain in an attempt to improve search-calling and precision, using the built-in ontology as the basis for a later extension of the user query in the search system. In [30], the authors provided an Arabic ontology that represents computer technology knowledge based on the Arabic Internet blogs. Research is conducting a pilot study on a number of randomly selected Arabic blogs in computer technology. Ontology comprised 110 classes, 78 class instances and 48 object properties, while others [31] also developed an ontology in computer technology based on classical Arabic rather than the modern language of blogs. Ontology presented is much simpler than what is discussed in [30].

sections.heading: 3. The Azhary System Architecture
sections.text: Azhary is a lexical ontology for the Arabic language, whose primary use is in automatic text analysis and artificial intelligence applications. It groups Arabic words into synonyms called synsets and records a number of relationships between words. Ontology comprises 26,195 words organized into 13,328 synsets. Azhary's system architecture, as shown in Figure 1, consists of several modules: The Words Extraction, The Relations Building, The Ontology Building, The Searching, and The Graphical User Interface.

sections.heading: 3.1 The Words Extraction
sections.text: This seed is composed of the Holy Quran, which contains 77,439 words. The primary function of this process is to trim the Quranic words and save these words without repetition in an Excel file containing the words and relationships in tabular form. Quran text comes from Tanzil [32] (an international Quran project), which provides a highly verified, accurate Quran text.

sections.heading: 3.2 The Relations Building
sections.text: The Relationship Building Module is a completely manual process in which it is achieved by using Arabic / Arabic dictionaries to find the words and build relationships between them. Common dictionaries, such as the meaning dictionary, are used in the construction of ontology. [33] The word can be linked to another word through the following semantic relationships: Synonym: B is a synonym for A if A and B have the same meaning. sections.heading: 4. Criticism and Comparison
sections.text: AWN as an Arabic lexicon has the largest number of words and synsets compared to the other Arabic words. But AWN has many disadvantages such as: 1- It has many errors in the meanings. Ex: If you use AWN to find the meaning of the verb fail, you will find (fail) in the results. 2-It has many words that repeat themselves.EX: If you use AWN to find the meaning of the verb speak or the noun travel, you will find many words that repeat themselves in the results.EX: If you use AWN to find the meaning of the verb speak or the noun travel, you will find many words that repeat themselves in the results. 3- A word may have different individual characteristics with themselves.EX: if you use AWN to find the meaning of the noun.

sections.heading: 5. The Conclusions
sections.text: There is no chance for Arabic semantic analysis as there is no Arabic lexical ontology that linguists can rely on. Therefore, in this paper we have introduced Azhary as an Arabic lexical ontology, whose primary use is in automatic text analysis and artificial intelligence applications. It groups Arabic words into groups of synonyms called synsets and records some relationships between words such as: synonym, antonym, hypernym, hyponym, meronym, holonym and association relationships. It has been developed and contrasted with AWN, the most commonly available Arabic lexical ontology. Our system shows better response times and it has larger words and records more word relationships.
